Comments.Message: Your computer is set to a broken DPI setting (which is also causing display irregularities in many other applications). Goto Display preferences, Advanced, and set the DPI setting back to Normal (96). It was probably set higher than normal by your OEM.

Just curious, why would a DPI setting other than 96 be "broken"? It sounds more like the application is broken if it does not operate correctly under various DPI settings. Users of Windows Vista might also be more likely to have a default system DPI setting other than 96.

The default system DPI is 96. Anything other than that is set by OEMs, or on very rare occasions, users. Windows Forms' implementation of it is broken, producing those results, when anything other than the default is used.

If I may suggest scaling the window. While setting the DPI to 96 may resolve the issue it breaks the environment around it.  In this particular case a high resolution screen laptop that become ~unreadable when the setting in changed. Like so many windows issues the application programmers end up being the most flexible.  Thanks in advance. Great program.

Scaling the window is not a possibility in Windows Forms. If this were Windows Presentation Foundation, we wouldn't have a problem. If your resolution is too high, lower your resolution. Using the broken DPI implementation is not a viable solution.
